description.div: Plant biology and associated careers through interaction with university, industry, and/or government agency biologists and/or upper division undergraduate students working in the various disciplines of plant biology.

Biology of plants grown for food, fiber, fun, or fuel. Plant life cycles in managed ecosystems and their role in global carbon and water cycles. Mechanisms plants use to drive and control their growth, propagate, and change to compete with other organisms in their environment.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 or parallel.

notes.div: AGRO 132 requires the completion of a plant science experiment.

description.div: Growth, development, morphology and staging of annual and perennial monocot and dicot plants produced for grain, forage and grazing. Evaluation of seed, grain and forage quality for plants of agronomic importance.

prerequisite.div: High school chemistry or one semester college chemistry.

description.div: Characteristics of soils in relation to their appropriate uses and protection. Principles and practices using cooperative exercises including discussion, assessment, planning, problem-solving, writing, and presentation involving all aspects of soils.

course.title: Current Topics in Plant Protection I

description.div: Microbe, insect, and weed pests of plants in agricultural, landscape, and natural ecosystems. Potential impacts of new scientific, regulatory, and international trade developments on plant pests management.

notes.div: Open only to freshmen or sophomores.

description.div: Group activities to help formulate career goals, improve academic success skills, develop a resume and select an appropriate internship.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 and AGRO/SOIL 153, or equivalents.

description.div: Integration of principles of crop and soil science, plant breeding, climatology and integrated pest management in the development and evaluation of crop management practices. Efficient use of solar radiation, water, nutrients, heat, carbon dioxide, and other resources in field crop management.

prerequisite.div: High school biology and chemistry. BIOS 101 and 101L, or 102 or equivalent recommended.

description.div: Plant breeding theory and technique. Application of genetic principles to plant improvement. Experience with breeding agronomic and horticultural plant species to illustrate plant mating systems and breeding principles.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 or HORT 130 or BIOS 109.

description.div: Introduction to turfgrasses, their management and use, and to the turfgrass industry.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 or BIOS 109.

notes.div: TLMT/AGRO/HORT/PGMP 228 uses a team approach to problem solving, discussion, assessment planning, and oral presentations of applied case studies.

description.div: An overview of landscape management and landscape design.  Principles and practices.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 or BIOS 109 or equivalent.

description.div: Principles basic to the establishment, management, and utilization of forage crops, pastures, and ranges. Plant identification and selection, seeding, fertilization, plant community manipulation, forage/range quality and utilization, and range management. The role of forages and ranges in developing a sustainable agriculture.

prerequisite.div: Permission, AGRO/RNGE 240 recommended.

description.div: Identification and description of two-hundred important wildland plants of North America. Characteristics of these plants evaluated in terms of management implications.

course.title: Current Topics in Plant Protection II

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing.

description.div: Microbe, insect, and weed pests of plants in agricultural, landscape, and natural ecosystems. Potential impacts of new scientific, regulatory, and international trade developments on plant pests management.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 153.

description.div: Principles of soil management under dryland and irrigated conditions. Relationships of soil and climate resources to soil erosion, movement and storage of soil water, soil organic matter, and irrigation practice. Special problem topics such as acidity, alkali, drainage, and soil testing.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs biological sciences.

description.div: Impact of exotic species and invasive organisms: agricultural and medical emerging disease; predicting biological invasions; biological control; regulatory, monitoring, and control efforts; ecological impact.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing and completion of internship approval form. The internship proposal is subject to approval by the department.

notes.div: P/N only. Written and oral report usually required.

description.div: Participation in agronomic applications and in agronomy-related areas of agribusiness; agronomic research in lab, greenhouse, or field; participation in farming practices other than those in which the student has had previous experience; or preparation of teaching materials.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 131 or 153 or HORT 130 or GEOG 140 or 155 or equivalent.

description.div: Historical, cultural and biophysical constraints of American agriculture through the integration of Web-based sources (USDA geospatial databases), geographic information systems, and spatial/temporal models. Introduction to crops and evolution of agriculture in North America and available digital resources (biogeoinformatics) to understand the patterns, trends, people, places and processes of rural landscapes.

prerequisite.div: 3 hrs biological sciences.

notes.div: Students with credit in BIOS 241 may register for 1 credit only.

description.div: Principles of inheritance in plants and animals and their significance in biology and agriculture. Emphasis on the physical basis of heredity in families and populations. Laboratory problems and experiments illustrate principles of heredity.

prerequisite.div: Chemistry through organic or higher-level course in cell biology.

notes.div: Botany recommended.

prerequisite.div: TLMT/AGRO/HORT/PGMP 227 or 228.

description.div: Using processes and problem-solving approach to identify and analyze common landscape management situations in commercial, public, and residential landscapes.  Integrate design, environment, function, pest and disease, and existing management practices to produce recommendations.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153; BIOS 109; CHEM 109 or parallel, or HORT 221.

description.div: Scientific principles of turf species adaptation, turf and/or soil relationships, establishment, fertility, mowing, irrigation, pest control, and vegetative identification of turf species.
Principles and procedures of turfgrass management equipment.  Current technology, acquisition, operation,  power trains, hydraulics, fuel systems, and maintenance of equipment.
Principles and procedures of landscape maintenance equipment, current technology, acquisition, operation,  maintenance of equipment, power trains, hydraulics, and fuel systems.

notes.div: TLMT/AGRO/HORT 330 will be offered during the last five-weeks of the second semester.

description.div: Why, when and how to prune ornamental landscape plants. Demonstrations and field opportunities on how to choose and how to use pruning tools correctly.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 240.

description.div: The principles of range management within the ecosystem framework. Range improvement practices and grazing systems; plant control using biological, chemical and mechanical factors; prescribed burning; range seeding; range fertilization; and the integration of range with other forage resources.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153; MATH 102 or 103; and one semester chemistry or equivalent.

description.div: Chemical and physical processes that influence the fate and transport of contaminants (inorganic, organic, microbial) in soil-water environments. Extent, fate, mitigation and impact of various sources of pollution. Remedial technologies used for environmental restoration of contaminated environments.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 153.

description.div: Use of fertilizers as plant nutrient sources to produce healthy and nutritious plants, improve profit, insure enterprise sustainability, fulfill legal requirements, and protect soil and water quality. Addresses issues from production agriculture, natural resource utilization and preservation, and ornamental plant culture.

prerequisite.div: 8 hrs biological sciences.

description.div: Survey of fungi in natural and human ecosystems: symbiotic relationships; as disease agents in humans, animals, and plants; applications in food, agricultural, and pharmaceutical industries; historical and current impacts on society.

course.title: Current Topics in Plant Protection III

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Microbe, insect, and weed pests of plants in agricultural, landscape, and natural ecosystems. Potential impacts of new scientific, regulatory, and international trade developments on plant pests management.

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing; HORT or AGRO or TLMT major.

notes.div: HORT/TLMT/AGRO 395 requires advanced permission before registering for the course. A written and oral report is required at the completion of the career experience.

description.div: Participation in a horticulture enterprise (other than in one of those in which the student has had previous experience).

notes.div: AGRO 403/803 (first eight weeks) and AGRO 404/804 (second eight weeks) constitute a basic one-semester course in field crop physiology and should be taken consecutively in the same semester.

description.div: Evaluation and appraisal of some contemporary aspects of crop physiology in major cereal and grain legume crops.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; AGRO 204, AGRO/SOIL 269; and permission. JGEN 200 and/or 300, and AECN 201 recommended.

notes.div: Capstone course. Requires participation in a three-day field trip prior to the beginning of the first semester. Students must notify instructor at time of early registration (dates are listed in Schedule of Classes). Cannot be taken "Pass/No Pass."

description.div: Application, expansion, and integration of principles from agricultural, biological, and physical sciences into the development and management of cropping systems.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; 4 hrs ecology; and 4 hrs botany or plant physiology.

notes.div: Offered fall semester of even-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Principles of plant physiology which underlie the relationship between plants and their physical, chemical and biotic environments. An introduction to the ecological niche, limiting factors and adaptation. An overview of the seed germination and ecology, plant and soil water relations, nutrients, plant energy budgets, photosynthesis, carbon balance and plant-animal interactions. An introduction to various field equipment used in ecophysiological studies.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing, MATH 106 or equivalent, 5 hrs physics, major in any of the physical or biological sciences or engineering; or permission.

description.div: Physical factors that create the biological environment. Radiation and energy balances of earth's surfaces, terrestrial and marine. Temperature, humidity, and wind regimes near the surface. Control of the physical environment through irrigation, windbreaks, frost protection, manipulation of light, and radiation. Applications to air pollution research. Instruments for measuring environmental conditions and remote sensing of the environment.

Basic steps required to produce genetically engineered crops. Genetic engineering procedures used to develop current crops and innovations that will lead to future products. Genetic engineering process and predicting how changes in different steps of the process influence the final crop. Application of genetic engineering technology to plan the development of new genetically engineered crops.

Application of classical and molecular genetic principles to the explanation of variation observed in plant families and populations. Interpretation of information gathered from whole plant trait observation and from molecular analysis. Relationships between crops and weeds. Examples from genetic studies on both crop and weed species are the basis of course.
Fundamental terminology associated with turfgrass and landscape weed management. Weed identification and the cultural practices and herbicide strategies to limit weed invasion and persistence.

prerequisite.div: BIOS/PLPT 369 or one semester of introductory plant pathology.

description.div: Pathogens, epidemiology, and control of diseases specific to turfgrass.

course.title: Applications of Remote Sensing in Agriculture and Natural Resources

prerequisite.div: GEOG/NRES 418.

description.div: Introduction to the practical uses of remote electromagnetic sensing in dealing with agricultural and water-resources issues.

prerequisite.div: AGRO 325 or basic course in plant physiology. A course in organic chemistry or biochemistry recommended.

notes.div: Offered spring semesters.

description.div: Macro and micro nutrient elements and their function in the growth and development of plants. Role of single elements. Interaction and/or balances between elements and nutrient deficiency and/or toxicity symptoms as they affect the physiology of the whole plant. Relationship between crop nutrition and production and/or environmental considerations (e.g. yield, drought, temperature, pests).

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153; BIOS 109.

description.div: Identification, biology and ecology of weedy and invasive plants. Principles of invasive plant management by preventative, cultural, biological, mechanical and chemical means using an adaptive management framework. Herbicide terminology and classification, plant-herbicide and soil-herbicide interactions, equipment calibration and dosage calculations.

prerequisite.div: 9 hrs agricultural plant science and 3 hrs soil sciences.

notes.div: TLMT/AGRO/HORT/PGMP 427 involves class discussion, case studies, field trips, and demonstrations. Capstone course.

description.div: Principles of turfgrass management and related contemporary issues. Concepts and problem solving approaches to turfgrass management.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; AGRO/SOIL 153;AGRO 204; or permission.

description.div: Principles and concepts of site-specific management. Evaluation of geographic information systems for crop production practices. Practical experience with hardware and software necessary for successful application of information affecting crop management.

prerequisite.div: BIOC/BIOS/CHEM 431/831.

notes.div: Offered every other year beginning spring 2007.

description.div: Biochemical metabolism unique to plants. Relationships of topics previously acquired in general biochemistry to biochemical processes unique to plants. Biochemical mechanisms behind physiological processes discussed in plant or crop physiology.

prerequisite.div: For AGRO/HORT/NRES 435: Senior standing or permission. For AGRO/NRES 835: 12 hrs biological or agricultural sciences or permission.

notes.div: Capstone course. Team projects for developing communication skills and leadership skills.

description.div: Integration of principles of ecology, plant and animal sciences, crop protection, and rural landscape planning and management for sustainable agriculture. Includes natural and cultivated ecosystems, population and community ecology, nutrient cycling, pest management, hydrologic cycles, cropping and grazing systems, landscape ecology, biodiversity, and socioeconomic evaluation of systems.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing.

notes.div: Cost of travel required. Summer travel course with multi-state faculty. Farm visits to Iowa, Minnesota and Nebraska.

description.div: Identification of grain quality characteristics desired by livestock feeders, human food processors and industrial users, and methods used to measure these characteristics.

course.title: Animal, Food and Industrial Uses of Grain

prerequisite.div: CHEM 105 or 109, and one of the following: AGRO 204 or ASCI 250.

description.div: Identification and comparison of grain quality characteristics desired by livestock feeders, human food processors and industrial users, and methods used to measure these characteristics.

course.title: Producing Grain for Animal, Food and Industrial Uses

prerequisite.div: CHEM 109 and one of the following: AGRO 204 or ASCI 250.

notes.div: AGRO 315 and 437/837 recommended.

description.div: Genetic development, production practices, and grain handling and storage procedures to deliver quality grain to livestock feeders, human food processors and industrial uses.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing. BIOS 101 and 101L, or equivalent, recommended.

description.div: Characteristics of Great Plains ecosystems, interrelationships of ecological factors and processes, and their application in the management of grasslands. Interactions of fire, vegetation, grazing animals and wildlife.

course.title: Perennial Plant Function, Growth, and Development

prerequisite.div: AGRO 325 or equivalent.

description.div: Principles of crop physiology and developmental morphology in relation to function, growth, development, and survival of perennial forage, range, and turf plants. The relationship of physiology and morphological development on plant use and management.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing. BIOS 101 and 101L, or equivalent, recommended.

description.div: Wildland plants that are important to grassland and shrub land ecosystem management and production. Distribution, utilization, classification, identification (including identification by vegetative parts), uses by Native Americans, and recognition of grasses, forbs, shrubs, exotic and wetland plants.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing. BIOS 101 and 101L, or equivalent, recommended.

description.div: Criteria by which grassland are analyzed. Vegetation sampling techniques, measurement and evaluation of grasslands, and measurement of important environmental factors. Evaluations of habitat improvement practices, wildlife value, recreational value, and watershed value.

course.title: Livestock Management on Range and Pasture

prerequisite.div: ASCI 250 and AGRO 240 or 340; AECN 201 recommended.

notes.div: Capstone course. All students required to participate in a one-week field trip in central or western Nebraska prior to beginning of fall semester. Therefore, students must notify instructor at time of early registration (Dates are given in class schedule.)

description.div: Analyzing the plant and animal resources and economic aspects of pasturage. Management of pasture and range for continued high production emphasized.

prerequisite.div: METR 200 or 351 or equivalent.

notes.div: Offered spring semester of even-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Impact of climate and extreme climatic events on society and societal responses to those events. Global in scope and interdisciplinary.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153.

description.div: Characteristics of soils in urban settings. Evaluation of soils intended for intensive human uses. Manipulation and remediation of soils subject to construction and other stresses.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153 or GEOL 101; CHEM 109 and 110; CHEM 221 or 251 or BIOC 221; or equivalent.

description.div: Chemical and mineralogical properties of soil components. Inorganic colloidal fraction. Structures of soil minerals as a means of understanding properties, such as ion exchange and equilibria; release and supply of nutrient and toxic materials; and soil acidity and alkalinity.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/SOIL 153, CHEM 116 or 221 or equivalent or permission.

notes.div: Permission required to register for 2 cr. Students registered for 3 cr will design, carry out, and report on an independent study project conducted during the term. Offered even-numbered calendar years. Lab 4-6.

description.div: Theory and practice of soil chemical analyses commonly encountered in research and industrial settings. Wet analyses of inorganic fraction of soil and operation of instrumentation necessary to quantify results of those analyses.

prerequisite.div: SOIL/AGRO/GEOL/WATS 361; PHYS 141 or equivalent; MATH 102 or 103.

notes.div: Capstone course. Lab 3, plus 3 hrs arr. Grad students in NRES/AGRO 458/858 or SOIL 458 are expected to carry out an independent project and give an oral report.

description.div: Survey of measurement techniques and principles used in characterizing the physical properties of soils. Includes analysis of experimental design and sources of experimental error. Techniques include: particle size analysis, soil water content, pore size analysis, field sampling techniques, soil strength, and saturated hydraulic conductivity.

prerequisite.div: One semester microbiology; one semester biochemistry or organic chemistry.

description.div: Soil from a microbe's perspective-growth, activity and survival strategies; principles governing methods to study microorganisms and biochemical processes in soil; mechanisms controlling organic matter cycling and stabilization with reference to C, N, S, and P; microbial interactions with plants and animals; and agronomic and environmental applications of soil microorganisms.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/SOIL 153; PHYS 141 or equivalent, one semester of calculus.

notes.div: Recommended: Parallel AGRO/NRES/SOIL 458.

description.div: Principles of soil physics. Movement of water, air, heat, and solutes in soils. Water retention and movement, including infiltration and field water regime. Movement of chemicals in soils.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; MATH 106; 4 hrs physics; physical or biological science major.

notes.div: Offered fall semester of odd-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Discussion and practical application of principles and practices of measuring meteorological and related variables near the earth's surface including temperature, humidity, precipitation, pressure, radiation and wind. Performance characteristics of sensors and modern data collection methods are discussed and evaluated.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/PGMP/TLMT 326.

notes.div: Form a landscape management company.

description.div: Using processes and strategies to identify and compare issues, make recommendations, demonstrate proficiency in field application as skills and techniques, and prepare cost estimates in the development of landscape management plans.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing or permission.

notes.div: Capstone course.

description.div: Holistic approach to the selection and analysis of planning strategies for protecting water quality from nonpoint sources of contamination. Introduction to the use of methods of analyzing the impact of strategies on whole systems and subsystems; for selecting strategies; and for evaluating present strategies.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/SOIL 153.

description.div: Spatial relationship of soil properties on various parts of landscape typical of the Plains, causal factors, and predictions of such relationships on other landscapes. Grouping these properties into classes, naming the classes, and the taxonomy that results from this grouping. Application of a taxonomy to a real situation through making a field soil survey in a region representative of the Plains border, predicting land use response of various mapped units as it affects the ecosystem, and evaluating the effectiveness of the taxonomic system used in the region surveyed.

prerequisite.div: AGRO/HORT/SOIL 153.

notes.div: TLMT/AGRO/HORT 480/880 is offered as a five week course.

description.div: Modified rootzones and their applications in the turfgrass and landscape management industry. Correct applications and construction techniques.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing or above or permission.

description.div: Seminar on current water resources research and issues in Nebraska and the region.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing, graduate standing, or permission.

description.div: Development converts rural landscapes into housing, roads, malls, parks, and commercial uses. This process fragments landscapes and changes ecosystem functions, drives up land prices, and pushes agriculture into more marginal areas.This multi-disciplinary, experiential course guides students in learning about the urbanization process, the impacts on landscapes, people, and the community, and the choices that are available to informed citizens.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing.

description.div: Topic varies and deals with different aspects of forage and/or range and/or livestock, turf and/or landscape grasses, natural habitats, and wetlands.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing.

notes.div: Capstone course. A two-semester sequence. Students should select one credit hour the first semester and three credits the second semester. The first semester will be used for planning, topic selection, and identifying a project adviser. The second semester will be used to carry out the research project, prepare a written report, and possibly an oral presentation.

description.div: Carry out and report on a research project.

prerequisite.div: Admission to the University Honors Program and permission, AGRI 299H recommended.

description.div: Conduct a scholarly research project and write a University Honors Program or undergraduate thesis.
